source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: internal pressures ranging from 0.34 to $1 . 3 8 ~ \mathbf { M P a }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: The measured diametral strains obtained at a heating rate of $5 ~ \mathbf { K } / \thinspace \mathbf { s }$ are plotted versus temperature in Fig. 7

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: at internal pressures greater than or equal to ${ \bf 0 . 6 9 M P a }$ (hoop stress of $1 1 . 3 \mathrm { M P a } ,$ there was little difference between the vacuum and steam data as negligible oxidation occurred during the short test period.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect of steam oxidation became important at lower pressures where the ramp temperatures exceeded $1 3 0 0 \textbf { K }$ , reducing the strain-rate of specimens tested in steam.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: Scanning electron microscope (SEM) examination of the surface of the pickled specimens deformed to different levels of strain at a magnification of $\times 5 0 0$ failed to reveal any oxide cracking at strains of up to 0.02.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: under a magnification of $\times 1 0 0 0 0$ , very fine cracks were observed at this strain and in some cases at a strain of 0.016.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: At high pressure (resulting in strain at lower temperature), cracks were numerous but fine and had little effect on ductility of the tube as oxidation layers were thin.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk2
evidence_span: At low pressures (resulting in strain at higher temperature) there were fewer cracks but they were deeper because the oxide layer was thicker.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: A series of temperature ramp tests at ambient internal pressure was performed in steam to investigate the effect of oxidation alone on strain of tubes in the absence of an applied stress.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: In specimens ramped to temperatures $\le 1 5 7 5 \ \mathbf { K }$ , the diametral strains based on inner and outer diameter had approximately the same values and both increased with increasing temperature.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: At higher temperatures, the inner-diameter strain seemed to reach a maximum between 0.5 and $0 . 7 \%$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: the outer-diameter strain increased with temperature up to $1 \%$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxide develops microscopic cracks at a strain of about $2 \%$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: Elastic modulus of the oxide $\pmb { { \cal E } }$ was estimated at $4 . 6 \times 1 0 ^ { 4 }$ MPa

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: the elastic hoop strain on formation $\left( \epsilon _ { f } \right)$ was set at $0 . 5 \%$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxide cracks when imposed strain on the outer fiber exceeds $1 . 8 \%$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk3
evidence_span: For every additional $0 . 5 \%$ strain on the uncracked oxide, an additional family of cracks having twice as many cracks as the previous family appears.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk6
evidence_span: Within the experimental conditions of this work the burst strain in steam was either to equal or smaller than the burst strain in inert atmosphere.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk6
evidence_span: Within the experimental conditions of this work the burst strain in steam was either to equal or smaller than the burst strain in inert atmosphere.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk6
evidence_span: Unpublished work by Hunt at Chalk River Nuclear Laboratories, however, indicates that there is enhancement of creep rate due to oxidation in Zircaloy during temperature ramp tests in steam in the $\pmb { \alpha }$ -phase temperature range, compared with tests in inert atmosphere.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: Our experiments showed that the oxide layer cracks anywhere between 1.6% and 2% strain.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: The specific value of 1.8% oxide cracking strain chosen in our model gave the best agreement between the model prediction and our data

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: Zircaloy-4 tubes were oxidized at temperatures ranging from 1173 to 1573 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: then compressed at 573 K to determine the embrittlement due to oxygen absorption

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: The simulated Zircaloy-clad fuel rods were burst and oxidized in steam at temperatures within the range 1200 to 1500 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: The segment sectioned from each burst cladding was also compressed to determine the effect of hydrogen absorption on cladding embrittlement

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: the additional embrittlement due to hydrogen absorption is found to be significant in burst cladding

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: The simulated Zircaloy clad fuel rods were burst and exposed to steam at isothermal temperatures ranging from 1173 to 1573 K

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: then bottom-flooded at the oxidation temperature or 773 K with water

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: The presence of restraining stress limits the permissible oxidation condition to lower temperature and shorter exposure time

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: Even the estimated thermal-shock-failure boundary under a restrained condition is located above the 15% oxidation line which is adopted by the present criteria

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_050_chunk7
evidence_span: The maximum clad temperature shall not exceed 1473 K
